fields.description:
When a [389DS|http://directory.fedoraproject.org/] directory has been created in Crowd, creating a group via the Crowd interface results in an LDAP Error 21 - invalid value for an attribute.

As per CWD-180, Crowd now creates groups with a null member value, so the group can be created. However, it seems that some directory servers such as 389DS do not allow null values; and will throw LDAP Error 21.

To work around this, administrators must create the groups in LDAP first, and sync them back to Crowd so they can be populated as per normal.

It would be nice if Crowd (for directory types that required it) had the ability to add at least one real member to the group as it's created to avoid this message.
fields.summary: When creating a group, require at least one member of the group that is not null if the directory type requires it

fields.description: When triggering a synchronisation of a remote directory from the UI, the logs will indicate that an incremental synchronisation is attempted, even when the directory is configured not to synchronise incrementally. Incremental synchronisation never occurs, but the logs are misleading and indicate that it could happen.

fields.description:
When looking at the following Confluence page regarding EOL, it is unclear as to whether the entire Crowd 2.7 family (including the above point releases) was EOL starting April 2016. 

https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-support-end-of-life-policy-201851003.html

Please update page with additional point versions or additional information.
fields.summary: Update EOL Crowd Documentation

fields.description:
Currently, admin.atlassian.com calls aid-crowd through the crowd client library. Wrong credentials cause aid-crowd to return a 500.

Find below the detailed call, captured on dev11 (ADA) to aid-crowd dev:
{quote}POST /crowd/services/SecurityServer HTTP/1.1
host: aid-crowd.dev.internal.atlassian.com
Accept-Encoding: gzip
Content-Type: text/xml; charset=UTF-8
SOAPAction: ""
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Crowd Client 2.6.0; XFire Client)
X-Real-IP: 172.26.40.14
X-Forwarded-For: 172.26.40.14, 172.26.40.14, 10.116.40.74
X-Forwarded-Port: 443
X-Forwarded-Proto: https
Content-Length: 933
Connection: keep-alive

<soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><soap:Body><ns1:authenticatePrincipal xmlns:ns1="urn:SecurityServer"><ns1:in0><name xmlns="http://authentication.integration.crowd.atlassian.com">ada</name><token xmlns="http://authentication.integration.crowd.atlassian.com">REDACTED</token></ns1:in0><ns1:in1><application xmlns="http://authentication.integration.crowd.atlassian.com">ada</application><credential xmlns="http://authentication.integration.crowd.atlassian.com"><credential>Pas$F</credential><encryptedCredential>false</encryptedCredential></credential><name xmlns="http://authentication.integration.crowd.atlassian.com">brjacobs</name><validationFactors xmlns="http://authentication.integration.crowd.atlassian.com"/></ns1:in1></ns1:authenticatePrincipal></soap:Body></soap:Envelope>

HTTP/1.1 500 Internal Server Error
Server: Apache-Coyote/1.1
Content-Encoding: gzip
Vary: User-Agent
Content-Type: text/xml;charset=UTF-8
Transfer-Encoding: chunked
Date: Fri, 15 Apr 2016 07:23:18 GMT
Connection: close



<soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><soap:Body><soap:Fault><faultcode>soap:Server</faultcode><faultstring>Account with name <brjacobs> failed to authenticate: User <brjacobs> does not exist</faultstring><detail><InvalidAuthenticationException xmlns="urn:SecurityServer"></InvalidAuthenticationException></detail></soap:Fault></soap:Body></soap:Envelope>

{quote}

Basically, this causes false positives in our monitoring systems as any user can trigger 500 errors when entering wrong credentials on ADA.
fields.summary: Crowd SOAP endpoint causing 500 when login fails

fields.description: Display the Server ID on the 'Add New License' page so that Administrators can easily locate and generate an evaluation key.
fields.summary: Display the Server ID on the 'Add New License' page

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Configuring a connector for Active Directory for Crowd and other applications shipping embedded Crowd is sometimes troublesome especially if the administrator configuring it has not deep knowledge of the AD structure.

h3. Suggested Solution
It would be nice to have the opportunity, once entered the AD server address and credentials, to browse the directory having and embedded browser and select a subset tree object to sync in Crowd.

Ideally the simplified sync should permit to select a set of groups to sync and synchronise all the selected groups with the related users.
fields.summary: As an Administrator I would like to have an Active Directory browser to configure my directory

fields.description: When adding an application (any type), pressing "Add Group" without selecting a group allows the "Select..." verbiage to be added. This is retained throughout the entire wizard, without throwing any errors. There should be validation added so this non-group cannot be added.
fields.summary: Add validation so "Select..." cannot be added as group

fields.description:
h4. Problem
There are certain versions of Crowd that do not work well together with certain application versions. The specific blacklisted version combination can only be derived from our public issue tracker.

h4. Suggestion
Create a Crowd/application compatibility matrix and make it publicly available, listing it on [the supported platforms documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Supported+Platforms].
fields.summary: Documentation request: Crowd compatibility matrix

fields.description: When adding an application to Crowd, the dropdown says "Stash". This is inconsistent with the application's new name "Bitbucket". This should be changed in the next release.
fields.summary: Rename Stash to Bitbucket to match product's rebrand

fields.description:
Atlassian GzipFilter duplicates functionality in Tomcat, for allowing clients to opt in to a compressed response. Remove it and configure Tomcat to use compression.

This is partially motivated by problems when upgrading to Tomcat 8; the simplification seems like an improvement as well.

As part of this change, the Crowd console will lose the ability to configure compression. However, the only value of that setting is to allow Crowd to ignore a client's request for a compressed response. That seems like an unlikely enough case that a (simple) change to the Tomcat configuration is an acceptable workaround.
fields.summary: Use Tomcat's compression instead of Atlassian GzipFilter

fields.description:
We find that we want all our users to share the same alias.

Our active directory names are of the form *first-initial+last-name* but our email addresses are *first-name.last-name*. We use the first part of the email address for user aliases on all our applications.
Example
|| AD Name || Email Address || Application Alias ||
| btest | broseph.test@example.com | broseph.test |

We'd like to have an option for automatic aliasing, based on existing user data and/or regex. It'd be best if these could be specified at the application level.

*Workaround*
We added a postgres trigger to "cwd_membership" to update aliases after a user membership is added.
fields.summary: Automatic aliasing

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When attempting to update a users email address to start with an uppercase letter, JIRA displays an error that an account with the same email address already exists.

h3. Environment
Cloud - JIRA v7.2.0-OD-05-030

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a user with an email address that contains all lowercase letters
# Edit the users email address by changing the first letter to uppercase
# Try to save the user details

h3. Expected Results

User details should save and either reflect the change or keep all letters lowercase

h3. Actual Results

JIRA displays an error indicating that a user with the same email address already exists

h3.Workaround
If you need to have an uppercase letter for the email address, this should be done when the user account is intially created
fields.summary: Error when changing case sensitivity of email address in existing account

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Local Crowd admin account is unable to login to Crowd when LDAP directory is locked out

h3. Environment
* Reproduced on Crowd 2.8.3 and Crowd 2.8.4
* Encryption method is atlassian-security
* Microsoft Active Directory server is first in order under *Applications > Crowd > Directories*
** Allow all to authenticate is set to True 
* Cache enabled is disabled

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Log out of Crowd (if logged in - to release the token)
# Login to crowd database with your favorite tool
# Run this to find the {{directory_id}} of the affected directory:
#* {{select * from cwd_directory_attribute where attribute_name='ldap.url';}}
# Copy the {{directory_id}} ex: 123456
# Paste it in place of {{<id>}} in the following query:
#* {{select * from cwd_directory_attribute where attribute_name='ldap.password' and directory_id=<id>;}}
#* example: {{select * from cwd_directory_attribute where attribute_name='ldap.password' and directory_id=123456;}}
# Replace {{<password>}} below with either a blank or incorrect password, then paste the same {{directory_id}} in place of {{<id>}} below:
#* {{update cwd_directory_attribute set attribute_value='' where attribute_name='ldap.password' and directory_id=<id>;}}
# Restart Crowd
# If the update was successful, you can no longer login to Crowd
#* If you are still able to login, log out (to release the token), then try to login again

h3. Expected Results
Local crowd admin user can login normally

h3. Actual Results
The user is unable to login and receives the following login error in the UI:
{code}Invalid login.{code}

The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-crowd.log file:
{code}Caused by: javax.naming.NamingException: [LDAP: error code 1 - 000004DC: LdapErr: DSID-0C090749, comment: In order to perform this operation a successful bind must be completed on the connection., data 0, v2580{code}

h3. Notes
* Seems like it could be related to [CWD-1763|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-1763], however this was fixed in 2.5.2 
* Uncertain what the user did in the UI that caused this, but there were changes in the UI made that changed the {{ldap.password}} to blank in the {{cwd_directory_attribute}} table. 
* Not caused by duplicate users

h3.Workaround
# Login to your crowd database with your favorite tool
# Run this to find the {{directory_id}} of the affected directory:
#* {{select * from cwd_directory_attribute where attribute_name='ldap.url';}}
# Copy the {{directory_id}} from the affected directory, ex: 654321
# Paste it in place of {{<id>}} in the following query:
#* {{select * from cwd_directory_attribute where attribute_name='ldap.password' and directory_id=<id>;}}
#* This shows the currently set password for ldap, which needs to be changed
#* Now, we need to modify this to use the correct ldap password
# Replace {{<password>}} below with the correct password, then paste the same {{directory_id}} in place of {{<id>}} below:
#* {{update cwd_directory_attribute set attribute_value='<password>' where attribute_name='ldap.password' and directory_id=<id>;}}
#* ex: {{update cwd_directory_attribute set attribute_value='myrealpassword' where attribute_name='ldap.password' and directory_id=123456;}}
# Restart Crowd 
# You should now be able to login with the local Crowd admin user
fields.summary: Local Crowd admin account is unable to login to Crowd when LDAP directory is locked out

fields.description:
When a user:
 - uses the "Change Password" feature in his crowd account
 - is forced by security policy (requiresPasswordChange=true) to update his password on next login to crowd

A custom message (configured in crowd backend by a crowd administrator) should be displayed.

In our case, we want to remind all users to disable external tools/scripts before password is changed in crowd. To prevent it from increasing the "login failed attemps" counter.

When password was changed a second custom message should be displayed (configured in crowd backend by a crowd administrator, too): To inform the user to update the password in all tools/scripts (e.g. Atlassian Connector for IntelliJ) and to re-enable all tools.
fields.summary: Change password dialog: add custom messages

fields.description:
We need to be able to manage a directory of customers. It is currently managed in the JIRA internal directory.

This allows us to not need user licenses since they do not get access to JIRA directly.

We would like to be able to manage the customer list incl. password management within Crowd -- but if we have a large number of customers, the licensing options becomes prohibitive.

We would like the ability to flag a user within Crowd as a "customer" and have it excluded from licensing limit -- these users would not have access to any other applications integrated with Crowd.

If a user in Crowd also is granted access to other applications, it is understood a license would be required.
fields.summary: Incorporate JIRA Service Desk "Customer" functionality

fields.description:
h2. Steps to reproduce
# In Crowd 2.8.4, navigate to Cogwheel Menu > LDAP connection pool
# Modify the values in each of the the connection pool settings
# Restart Crowd
# Go back to the same page

h2. Expected results
The "LDAP connection pool statistics" report at the top will reflect the connection pool settings previous inputted

h2. Actual results
The "LDAP connection pool statistics" report shows the same starting values each time:
{code}
***** start *****
idle timeout: 0
maximum pool size: 0
preferred pool size: 0
initial pool size: 1
protocol types: plain ssl
authentication types: none simple 
...
{code}

h2. Other notes
In earlier versions of Crowd, such as 2.8.0, the "LDAP connection pool statistics" report is not available from the UI. However, one can still validate that Crowd is still affected by this issue by setting the following JVM startup parameter:
{code}
-Dcom.sun.jndi.ldap.connect.pool.debug=all
{code}

The same LDAP connection report can be seen at the very beginning of Crowd startup in Tomcat logs, at <crowd_install>/apache-tomcat/logs/catalina.out

h2. Workaround
Setting the parameters directly via JVM parameters still works:
{code}
com.sun.jndi.ldap.connect.pool.authentication
com.sun.jndi.ldap.connect.pool.debug
com.sun.jndi.ldap.connect.pool.initsize
com.sun.jndi.ldap.connect.pool.maxsize
com.sun.jndi.ldap.connect.pool.prefsize
com.sun.jndi.ldap.connect.pool.protocol
com.sun.jndi.ldap.connect.pool.timeout
{code}

Reference: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/jndi/tutorial/ldap/connect/config.html
fields.summary: LDAP connection pool settings are not being respected

h3. Summary
Users that has been granted Admin rights in Crowd Application does not have any Admin rights and is not distinguishable than Non-Administrators users

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a group called 'crowd-system-administrators' in the Crowd internal directory
# Insert the user 'poweruser' to this group
# Go to Crowd Admin > Applications > Crowd > Directories > Make sure Allow All to Authenticate is set to "True" for Crowd internal directory
# Go to Crowd Admin > Applications > Crowd > Groups > Add crowd-system-administrators, and give this group *only* "Admin" rights (make sure System Administrator is unticked):
!image-2016-03-17-21-35-15-349.png|thumbnail! 
# Login as 'poweruser' into Crowd

h3. Expected Results
User 'poweruser' able to administer Crowd to a certain level, although does not have all privileges such as those belong to 'crowd-administrators' right

h3. Actual Results
User 'poweruser' does not have any privilege to administer anything in crowd, except the 'Self-Service Console' that Non-Administrators user also able to access
 !image-2016-03-17-21-34-53-885.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Suggestions:
# Have a different level of "Administration" Function
# If the rights "Admin" is to be able to administer own account, the "Admin" is quite misleading and should be changed to "User"
fields.summary: No difference between users that has "Admin" rights and Non-Administrators users

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
As of now, there's no indication in our [Integrating Crowd with Apache|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Integrating+Crowd+with+Apache] documentation that [Crowd Apache/Subversion Connector|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.crowd.connectors.apache/server/overview] plugin is no longer supported, even though this plugin is officially not supported since 31st December 2014 as outlined in [Integrating Crowd with Subversion|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Integrating+Crowd+with+Subversion] documentation.

h3. Suggested Solution
To update [Integrating Crowd with Apache|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Integrating+Crowd+with+Apache] documentation to specify that [Crowd Apache/Subversion Connector|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.crowd.connectors.apache/server/overview] plugin is not supported anymore.
fields.summary: Update on "Integrating Crowd with Apache" Documentation

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Crowd directory synchronisation stalls if the first 10 directory synchronisation hits into any error such as LDAP response read timed out. This would cause the remaining directories (apart from the first 10) to not be synchronised at all. Note that, manual synchronisation of these directories will still work. 

h3. Possible Steps to Reproduce (not consistently reproducible)
# Create more than 10 LDAP directories in Crowd
# Wait for the 10 directories to synchronise (try to make the directory synchronisation to fail by shutting down the LDAP server midway through the synchronisation and bring up the server again)

h3. Expected Results
The remaining directories other than the first 10 directories should still be synchronised

h3. Actual Results
The remaining directories other than the first 10 directories will never be synchronised

h3.Workaround
Manually synchronise each of the remaining directories one by one or reduce the amount of directories to below than 10

h3. Notes
We suspect this is due to limitation in Quartz and it's similar or closely related to this KB: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFKB/Scheduled+jobs+may+stall+and+fail+to+process+if+one+job+becomes+stuck. Crowd uses Quartz, a third party library for scheduling tasks.
# Individual jobs are submitted to one of 10 worker threads.
# When a job starts running, it takes a lock on an object, that all the other threads will be looking for.
** Only one thread can be running at any given time, they'll be waiting until it's free
# Once the job completes, the running thread will release the lock
** The remaining threads will check if they are able to start every 500ms

If a problem occurs during the job execution for example, LDAP response read timed out problem, then the running thread will stall and never release it's lock; and other threads will not be able to start their jobs causing the remaining directory synchronisation to never runs.

As a suggestion, when one of the directory fails to synchronise, we should release the lock so that other threads will be able to start their jobs and the remaining directories will be synchronised automatically.
fields.summary: Crowd directory synchronisation stalls if the first 10 directory synchronisation hits into any error

fields.description:
Seems a [change|https://stash.atlassian.com/projects/CWD/repos/crowd/pull-requests/161/diff] in Crowd 2.8.4 causes the Crowd base url to be resolved incorrectly.

The URL entered in the UI/migrated from pre-4.0 (which is stored in the db as crowd.server.url) is loaded as crowd.base.url for ClientProperties. This causes com.atlassian.crowd.service.client.ClientPropertiesImpl#generateBaseURL never to be called,p and the entered url is used as a base url, which wasn't the case pre-2.8.4.

This causes a 'CROWD/services' url to no longer work when entered as a remote Crowd URL, where previously it did.
fields.summary: Base URL no longer resolved properly in Crowd 2.8.4

fields.description:
As a normal user (not admin) in Atlassian Crowd, there is no method to trigger a password reset as you need to have Crowd application permissions for the "Forgot my password" link to run. 

This means that the Crowd admin has to find the user, and trigger it on their behalf.

There's also no documented method to trigger the password reset function via the API. 

While you can set a password via the API, it would be good to be able to trigger the existing web workflow.

h3. Suggestion
- There should be a default method for the normal user to reset the password. 
- There's a need for a password rest function via API
fields.summary: User password reset

fields.description:
According to [Crowd REST APIs|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/CROWDDEV/Crowd+REST+APIs], *POST /user* can be used to create a new user, and that user will be created in the first writeable directory in directory order for the application making the request. 

As an improvement, we could allow the ability to specify a directory when adding users. This could make the process more transparent and give the administrator more control by taking out the element of chance, in the event the administrator is unaware of the directories mapped to an application and the order they're in.
fields.summary: Allow new users to be created in specific directories via the REST API

The signal is triggered after the database has been setup and the plugin system is started for the first place, but it is muted in {{DefaultLifecycleManager}} because at that point the setup process is not complete.

When the setup process is complete and the application is ready to receive requests, no signal is given to the LifecycleAware components.

This causes problems for some plugins, like Atlassian Healthcheck, which reports "unhealthy" due to https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/AHC-47

1) Make sure the artifacts necessary for development are available for both gradle and maven (Gradle has stricter dependency resolution than maven, which causes breakage with an invalid Pom.xml for the org.apache.ws group)

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, although the application name needs to be unique there is no check in place to ensure a duplicate name is not entered. If a duplicate name is entered there are no errors in the UI or the logs indicating a duplicate name already exists, and Crowd allows it to be added without any indication it will cause authentication failures. 

The documentation states "The username which the application will use when it authenticates against the Crowd framework as a client. This value must be unique, i.e. it cannot be used by more than one application client.", however, there is no check in place to ensure duplicate names are not created. 

The condition is difficult to diagnose as there is no indication that a duplicate name is used. 

h3. Suggested Solution
As an admin, I would like there to be a check in Crowd's 'Add Application' Wizard to notify me if the application name is a duplicate before submitting so that I can ensure the name is unique.
fields.summary: Check for duplicate Application names when adding a new application

fields.description:
Crowd is vulnerable to [Clickjacking|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clickjacking]. That is, it is possible to frame crowd from a page hosted in a different domain and trick the user into performing an action they did not intend to perform, for example changing their display name.

This issue can be addressed by using the [{{X-Frame-Options}}|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clickjacking#X-Frame-Options] header and or through the [CSP frame-ancestors directive| https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clickjacking#Content_Security_Policy]. When fixing this issue we need to ensure that resources that need to be able to be framed are still allowed to be framed, e.g. gadget resources.
fields.summary: Enable X-FRAME-Option in HTTP response headers in order to provide clickjacking protection

fields.description:
In case a server has multiple interfaces, it's not possible to determine at which interface outgoing traffic will be sent to, so it's suggested to add all the addresses to a directory configuration to accept connections from all of them.

The suggestion is to change the documentation [https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Specifying+an+Application's+Address+or+Hostname], right after the second paragraph:

bq. When you add a new application, you will specify the application's IP address. After adding the application, you can update the IP address if necessary, as described below. In some cases, you may need to add the applicable host name as well as the IP address.

The suggestion is to also cover the multiple interfaces scenario - either suggesting to include all the IPs in the list of allowed IPs for the application, or not recommending this setup at all.
fields.summary: Update on the "Specifying an Application's Address or Hostname" document, for multiple interfaces

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The embedded crowd library that comes with applications such as Confluence/JIRA/Stash does not respect the proxyHost parameter (used to connect to forwarding proxies), when trying to obtain users from another server (such as JIRA/Crowd/LDAP)

h3. Environment
You have an environment that requires forwarding proxy to forward requests from Confluence/JIRA/Crowd to another server (where the users are stored, could be AD/Crowd/LDAP/JIRA) 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Setup Confluence
# Add the proxyHost parameter to Confluence's JVM parameters (example):
{code}
-Dhttp.proxyHost=proxy.test.com -Dhttp.proxyPort=3128
{code}
Modify it accordingly to fit your forwarding proxy configuration
# Make sure JIRA is contactable from Confluence, only via the forwarding proxy
# Start up Confluence, and setup JIRA user management. This will fail with this error:
{code}
2015-12-01 12:57:58,790 ERROR [TP-Processor10] [crowd.embedded.admin.ConfigurationController] onSubmit Configuration test failed for user directory: [ JIRA Server], type: [ CROWD ]
 -- referer: https://confluence.test:8090/plugins/servlet/embedded-crowd/configure/jira/?xsrfTokenName=atl_token&xsrfTokenValue=83233435434634b3b60c3d600bfa4ae2ba546 | url: /plugins/servlet/embedded-crowd/configure/jira/ | userName: test
com.atlassian.crowd.exception.runtime.OperationFailedException: org.apache.http.conn.HttpHostConnectException: Connect to jira.test:8010 [jira.test/12.12.24.25] failed: Network is unreachable
	at com.atlassian.crowd.embedded.core.CrowdDirectoryServiceIm
{code}
# Setup Application Links with JIRA via the same URL. This will succeed (proof that only embedded Crowd is affected)

h3.Workaround
No known workaround, except to make sure that JIRA/Crowd/LDAP is contactable without the forwarding proxy
fields.summary: Embedded Crowd Does Not Respect the ProxyHost Parameter When Connecting to LDAP/Crowd/JIRA

fields.description:
Said errors are appearing in our Crowd logs a bit. Not a massive amount, but 50-100 occurrences per day. Can't really tell if it's actually causing anything or not though.

We migrated our user data from a Crowd 2.7.x version to 2.8.3 earlier, and these started appearing pretty much at that point.
{code:java}
ERROR: duplicate key value violates unique constraint "uk_token_id_hash"{code}
{code:java}
Exception executing batch [could not perform addBatch]{code}
This seems more or less the same as [https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWDKB/Crowd+hanging+after+upgrade+to+2.7], and perhaps CWD-3688, although it was supposedly fixed in 2.7.1 (we are running 2.8.3).
{code:java}
2015-12-09 02:04:56,760 ajp-bio-8011-exec-8447 WARN [engine.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper] SQL Error: 0, SQLState: 23505
2015-12-09 02:04:56,760 ajp-bio-8011-exec-8447 ERROR [engine.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper] Batch entry 0 insert into cwd_token (directory_id, entity_name, random_number, identifier_hash, random_hash, created_date, last_accessed_date, last_accessed_time, duration, id) values (-1, 'jira', 4708640468633722119, 'hVtW5FElx8qNjHjM06Kw8A00', 'P7bz06P1t18hRS4vJ0OCfg00', '2015-12-09 02:04:56.756000 +02:00:00', '2015-12-09 02:04:56.756000 +02:00:00', 1449619496756, 60, 5747171) was aborted.  Call getNextException to see the cause.
2015-12-09 02:04:56,760 ajp-bio-8011-exec-8447 WARN [engine.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper] SQL Error: 0, SQLState: 23505
2015-12-09 02:04:56,760 ajp-bio-8011-exec-8447 ERROR [engine.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper] ERROR: duplicate key value violates unique constraint "uk_token_id_hash"
  Detail: Key (identifier_hash)=(hVtW5FElx8qNjHjM06Kw8A00) already exists.
2015-12-09 02:04:56,760 ajp-bio-8011-exec-8447 ERROR [jdbc.batch.internal.BatchingBatch] HHH000315: Exception executing batch [could not perform addBatch]
{code}
{code:java}
2015-12-09 11:42:57,933 ajp-bio-8011-exec-8698 WARN [engine.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper] SQL Error: 0, SQLState: 23505
2015-12-09 11:42:57,933 ajp-bio-8011-exec-8698 ERROR [engine.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper] Batch entry 0 insert into cwd_token (directory_id, entity_name, random_number, identifier_hash, random_hash, created_date, last_accessed_date, last_accessed_time, duration, id) values (-1, 'repo-hiq-fi-subversion', 1732528840858537267, 'NRNepD5oLeamwJtpub0tFQ00', '25P22OgqoPXQMBd3BK9Z7w00', '2015-12-09 11:42:57.924000 +02:00:00', '2015-12-09 11:42:57.924000 +02:00:00', 1449654177924, 60, 5747585) was aborted.  Call getNextException to see the cause.
2015-12-09 11:42:57,933 ajp-bio-8011-exec-8698 WARN [engine.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper] SQL Error: 0, SQLState: 23505
2015-12-09 11:42:57,933 ajp-bio-8011-exec-8698 ERROR [engine.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper] ERROR: duplicate key value violates unique constraint "uk_token_id_hash"
  Detail: Key (identifier_hash)=(NRNepD5oLeamwJtpub0tFQ00) already exists.
2015-12-09 11:42:57,933 ajp-bio-8011-exec-8698 ERROR [jdbc.batch.internal.BatchingBatch] HHH000315: Exception executing batch [could not perform addBatch]
{code}
h2. What does this error mean?

Crowd has just created a new session token for a user or an integrated application which has just authenticated, and it is trying to insert the token in the database. Unfortunately the database rejects the insertion because the "new" token violates a unique constraint on the token's identifier hash column.

Crowd will acknowledge that a faster insert of a new token has already happened, the contents of the cwd_token table have changed, and will reuse the other token that was inserted since they are equivalent. Because Crowd recovers from the failed insertion, *this error does not cause any request to fail*.
h2. Workaround

Switch Crowd to use [in-memory token management|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/session-configuration-17956967.html] (not available in Crowd Data Center). Otherwise the error messages may be safely disregarded.
fields.summary: Exception executing batch [could not perform addBatch] errors being logged

fields.description:
CWD-1469 introduced a REST API to manage user aliases.

Because aliases refer to usernames, they become orphaned when a user is renamed or deleted (CWD-2179). The orphans are difficult to track and eliminate, and they stay behind occupying the alias name and preventing new users (or the renamed user) from re-using the alias.

The current REST API (CWD-1469) offers a solution: the aliases can be listed, removed and added individually. However, if the number of applications is high, that involves 1+2N calls.

As a REST client, I would like to have an API in Crowd to change or delete all the aliases (for all applications) for a username.
fields.summary: REST API to bulk change or delete user aliases

fields.description:
Crowd presents the 'Setup' page, even after configuration.

This makes the 'Setup' page visible to *anyone* by default.

Login is still required, but I would prefer not to advertise or confuse users.

How can I work around this without using an http server with a rewrite rule?
fields.summary: A configured Crowd instance still presents the 'Setup' page

fields.description:
A disabled group still counts towards the Crowd license, even though no user from that group would be able to log into the mapped application.

h3.Steps to replicate
# Create a new application in Crowd
# Create a group in the Crowd Internal Directory called _Test_
# Create a new user in the Crowd Internal Directory and add this user to the _Test_ group
# Go to the new application we've just created and set the Crowd Internal Directory _Allow all to authenticate_ as false under the Directories tab
# Now under the _Groups_ tab of this application add the Test group to allow authentication
# Check under the Crowd Licensing (recalculate if needed) how many users are counting
# Now go the the Test group and disable the _Test_ group
# Now under the Crowd Licensing make sure to recalculate

h3.Expected Results
License count would exclude users from that group since they are not able to log into that application, just as it is when we disable a directory.

h3.Current results
The new user is still counting towards the license, even though right now *no* user will be able to log into the new application.
fields.summary: Disabled Group Still Counts Towards the License

fields.description: Added a new directory that connects to Active Directory and then Crowd determined that the number of users exceeded the license and will not let us back into Crowd to change or remove the new directory.  I have to get an evaluation license so I can get back in to Crowd to correct the new directory.  Fortunately this happened in a test environment, it would have been very bad to happen in Production.
fields.summary: Add a directory and Crowd determines you have too many users for your license and you can't get back in to Crowd to modify or remove the new directory

fields.description:
We have 80,000 user in our internal directory, and it took over 5 hours to upgrade versions of crowd.  After speaking with a support engineer, this was considered an acceptable downtime to Atalssian.  In fact, I was asked by them to plan for another 2 hours in production, just in case.

A 7 hour outage for an enterprise application is not only unacceptable but also shameful for Atlassian to consider it a reasonable time for an upgrade.

Please consider figuring out a better was to upgrade your database than line by line update statement. Create a load file, perhaps?
fields.summary: Upgrade task that generates externalIds (623) takes a long time to execute

fields.description: This information can be added to the cwd_membership table. This is good for auditing purposes, and for admins to determine when a user has access to any resource that are group-restricted.
fields.summary: Record the date that a user is added to a group (membership added date)

fields.description:
Oftentimes it's not entirely clear what a group is used for by its name alone, so we're adding descriptions for every group.

This isn't as useful as it could be, because the Group Search results returns just the group name and whether the group is active.  

There is plenty of screen real estate so the group description could be displayed as well.
fields.summary: Group Search results should include Group Description

fields.description:
In order to provide additional auditing options, it'd be nice if Crowd allowed for administrators to retrieve the timestamp of the latest login from an user in specific applications.

This is currently stored on the {{cwd_user_attributes}} table within the {{lastAuthenticated}} attribute, however it's updated on any login performed by the user in any connected application.
fields.summary: Store last login dates in a per-application basis

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Crowd does not see universal groups unless it is directly part of the domain. 

h3. Suggested Solution
Have Crowd detect universal groups regardless of the domain it is a part of.
fields.summary: As a Crowd admin I want AD universal groups to be discovered when they are not located directly in the domain

fields.description:
There is no more Stash due to rebranding
https://www.atlassian.com/software/crowd/overview

We should change the piture on this page to follow Stash ->Bitbucket Server rebranding
fields.summary: Replace picture with new Bitbucket product logo instead of Stash

fields.description:
I'd like to request somewhat more detailed error messages when errors are encountered resetting a user's password in Crowd.

Currently, when connected to a Microsoft AD using the connector, if there is a problem resetting the password (usually when the proposed password doesn't meet complexity, reuse, etc) requirements, the raw LDAP error code is passed to the user, which is usually some variation on "WILL_NOT_PERFORM" with other identifiers.

This almost always results in the user contacting our Crowd admins since it looks like a permission problem; they don't know/can'tsee their password is being rejected for not meeting domain security policy.

Ideally, the error message would include verbiage to the effect of "Try a different password".
fields.summary: Better error messages for AD connected password resets

fields.description: We authenticate users based on employeeid field in active directory. We gave over 30 running projects with different administrators. If for some rwason one of the records has a space or a special character in the enployeeid field the whole sync with active directory goes dow. We are using confluence.
fields.summary: When synchronization with ldap if a single record has special character the whole sync goes down

fields.description: It would be helpful to have a second / "Failover URL" entry (though not make it required) in the LDAP Connector screen on the Connector tab.  This would allow for failover/redundancy in situations when the primary LDAP server goes down and the failover server is still operational and could also reduce maintenance complications when LDAP servers need to be upgraded or replaced.
fields.summary: Allow second LDAP server to be listed in the LDAP connector for failover / redundancy

fields.description: Currently {{cwd_user}} table in Crowd contains {{created_data}} column that shows when the user created. However, it'd be useful to add a column that shows who created this user. It's useful for administrators to know who created a particular user in Crowd instance.
fields.summary: Show a creator of user in Crowd database
Propagate synch.* group attribute changes to the remote directory
Support group attribute synchronisation in incremental Crowd-to-Crowd sync

fields.description: This resource should not fail for trivial renames. Failing means that the client must do an extra check before making the request.
fields.summary: /user/rename should allow trivial renames
